column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.ner.type.NamedEntity|identifier|value
#Text=# AltEntities (Alternative Entities) dataset: Resolving Indirect Referring Expressions for Entity Selection
#Text=
#Text=## COPYRIGHT NOTICE
#Text=
#Text=This is the work of *Mohammad Javad Hosseini*, *Filip Radlinski*, *Silvia Pareti*, and *Annie Louis* from Google LLC, made available under the CC-BY SA 3.0 License.
#Text=A full copy of the license can be found at https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/
#Text=
#Text=## The Dataset
#Text=
#Text=AltEntities is a dataset of English-language **alternative questions with their answers**.
#Text=In these questions, a user is presented with a choice of two entities.
#Text=The user answer intends to **select one entity from the pair by referring to it in an indirect way, i.e., without referring to its name or position**.
#Text=For example:
#Text=
#Text=Question: “Do you mean 'Nemesis (Davis novel)' or 'Nemesis (Christie novel)'?”
#Text=Answer: “Not the more modern one, the one closer to BC than 2021.”
#Text=The entity names are sampled from Wikipedia.
#Text=The alternative questions are generated using a simple template.
#Text=The referring expressions are provided by human raters.
#Text=The dataset contains **6,247 alternative questions in three domains--books, songs (music), and recipes--and 42,529 referring expressions**.
#Text=The dataset is suitable for building machine learning systems to resolve indirect referring expressions for entity selection.

#Text=A full description of the data collection methodology, analyses, human rater instructions, and the performance of the SOTA LLMs can be found in the associated research [paper](https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.10933).
#Text=Further details about the data are provided in [Data-Description.pdf](Data-Description.pdf)
#Text=
#Text=## Explanation of the Data Files
#Text=
#Text=The data is released in a json format with each example (json object) representing one alternative question along with its referring expressions.
#Text=Each example has the following fields:
#Text=
#Text=* domain: The domain of the example: “BOOKS”, “RECIPES”, or “SONGS”.
#Text=* question: An alternative question providing two choices.
#Text=* target: The URL of the target entity.
#Text=* target_index: The index (position) of the target entity in the question (0 or 1).
#Text=* sampling_method: The sampling method used to sample the entities in the question (e.g., SAME_NAME, SIMILAR_NAME, or SIMILAR_DESCRIPTION).
#Text=* description_section: The title of the Wikipedia section shown to crowd workers.
#Text=If empty, indicates the first section.
#Text=This does not apply to the "SONGS" domain.
#Text=* choices: Information about the two choices.
#Text=See below fields for more information.
#Text=* choice/name: The name of the choice.
#Text=* choice/wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL of the choice.
#Text=* choice/description: The choice description shown to crowd workers.
#Text=* choice/infobox: Textual representation of the choice’s Wikipedia infobox.
#Text=* choice/unshown_background: The choice/infobox above concatenated with Wikipedia sections that were *not* shown to crowd workers.
#Text=* expressions: Referring expressions written by crowd workers to select the target entity.
#Text=The *data* directory contains the full set of examples (*all.json*).
#Text=For each domain (*books*, *recipes*, and *songs*), a subdirectory contains all its examples which are split into *train.json*, *dev.json*, and *test.json*.
#Text=In addition, the mixed subdirectory contains the mix of examples in the three domains.
#Text=
#Text=## Citation
#Text=The paper and the dataset can be cited as:
#Text=
#Text=```
#Text=@article{hosseini2022resolving,
#Text=  title={Resolving Indirect Referring Expressions for Entity Selection},
#Text=  author={Hosseini, Mohammad Javad and Radlinski, Filip and Pareti, Silvia and Louis, Annie},
#Text=  journal={arXiv preprint arXiv:2212.10933},
#Text=  year={2022}
#Text=}
#Text=```
